required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Use of Ultrasound Guidance to Facilitate Obtaining Peripheral Intravenous Access
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Ultrasound Guidance to Facilitate Insertion of Peripheral Intravenous Catheter in Pediatric Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if the use of ultrasound guidance to insert peripheral intravenous catheters will decrease the number of punctures required to successful insertion. The hypothesis is that fewer attempts will be required with the use of ultrasound potentially leading to preservation of vessels, decreased patient pain scores and increased patient/parent satisfaction.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients with known or current difficult venous access will be referred to the Vascular Access Team for peripheral intravenous catheter insertion. The Vascular Access Team will randomize patients to ultrasound guidance or non-ultrasound guidance for placement of the peripheral intravenous catheter.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of attempts to successful peripheral intravenous access cannulation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient pain score rating for PIV access attempt.

other_outcome.measure: Parent satisfaction with child's PIV access experience.

other_outcome.description: Cincinnati Children's Hospital has an initiative to reduce the number of PIV extravasations. The investigators will measure the number of extravasations in the study participants to determine if ultrasound guidance has an effect on this number.

arm_group.description: Ultrasound guidance used to facilitate insertion of PIV catheter.
Ultrasound guidance will not be used for insertion of PIV catheter.

intervention.description: Ultrasound guidance used to facilitate insertion of PIV catheter
Ultrasound guidance will not be used for insertion of PIV catheter

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients 0-17 years of age requiring peripheral intravenous access
- have not had PIV attempt in preceding 24 hours
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients who are medically unstable
- patients who require emergent intravenous access
